item.title: Dow Ends Above 10K, a First in 18 Months (AP)
item.description: AP - The Dow Jones industrial average closed just above 10,000 Thursday, a milestone not seen in 18 months that encompassed a painfully deep dive in stocks as well as a surprisingly vigorous rebound.

item.title: Halliburton May Have Overcharged Millions (AP)
item.description: AP - Pentagon auditors found that Vice President Dick Cheney's former company may have overcharged the Army by as much as $61 million for gasoline in Iraq, senior defense officials said Thursday.

item.title: Iraq Suicide Attack Kills 1 U.S. Soldier (AP)
item.description: AP - Three suicide bombers in a furniture truck blew themselves up at the gates of a U.S. Army base Thursday, killing one soldier and wounding 14. It was the third suicide attack on American troops in Iraq this week. Meanwhile, three loud explosions boomed early Friday in the "Green Zone," the compound housing the headquarters of the U.S.-led coalition, in central Baghdad.

item.title: Flu Outbreak Now Widespread in 24 States (AP)
item.description: AP - The number of states hit hard by the flu has nearly doubled to 24 in the past week, the government said Thursday as it rushed to ship 100,000 doses of the vaccine to combat shortages and head off what could become one of the worst flu seasons in years.

item.title: Gaps Found N.D. Student Suspect's Story (AP)
item.description: AP - Investigators found about a three-hour gap between the time a North Dakota college student disappeared and the time the suspect in the case arrived home, according to a search warrant unsealed Thursday.

item.title: WTC Site Architects Claim Cooperation (AP)
item.description: AP - Despite reports of bitter feuding, two renowned architects said Thursday they're working together to complete a plan by next week for a 1,776-foot tower at the World Trade Center site.

item.title: AP: Israeli Talks Settlement Withdrawal (AP)
item.description: AP - Israel may soon be compelled to dismantle a "considerable" number of Jewish settlements and draw a border around the rest, Israel's vice premier told The Associated Press on Thursday — a go-it-alone approach he suggested has Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's tacit backing.

item.title: Two Facing Charges in Spamming Operation (AP)
item.description: AP - Using the nation's toughest anti-spam law for the first time, Virginia prosecutors have gained felony indictments against two men accused of sending thousands of unsolicited e-mail pitches for investments, software and other products.

item.title: Serena Williams Signs Deal With Nike (AP)
item.description: AP - Serena Williams can start putting a swoosh on the tennis outfits she designs. Williams agreed to terms on a sponsorship contract with Nike, a deal that could be worth close to $40 million over five years, a tennis source told The Associated Press on Thursday.

item.title: Capitals, With New Coach, Beat Bruins 6-5 (AP)
item.description: AP - Maybe a coaching change was all the Washington Capitals needed. Playing with more speed and energy, the Capitals made coach Glen Hanlon's debut a successful one, scoring three quick first-period goals in a 6-5 victory over the Boston Bruins on Thursday night.

item.title: Car Bomb at Iraq Base Kills One U.S. Soldier, Wounds 14 (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - A suicide car bomb attack at a U.S. military base in Iraq on Thursday killed one U.S. soldier and wounded 14 as troops uncovered a weapons cache north of Baghdad with enough ammunition to launch a spate of strikes.

item.title: Stocks Rally, Dow Closes Above 10,000 (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - The Dow industrials closed above 10,000 for the first time in nearly 19 months on Thursday, after the Federal Reserve indicated it would keep interest rates low for some time.

item.title: Pentagon: Halliburton May Have Overcharged in Iraq (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - A Pentagon audit of Halliburton, the oil services firm once run by Vice President Dick Cheney, found the company may have overbilled the U.S. government by more than $120 million on Iraq contracts, U.S. defense officials said on Thursday.

item.title: Flu Spreading in U.S. But Not Scary Yet -Officials (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - The flu is spreading across the United States and the government is concerned enough to buy up 250,000 available doses of vaccine to make sure it goes to those who need it most, officials said on Thursday.

item.title: N.Korea Nuclear Talks Seen Delayed to Mid-January (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - Six-country talks to try to halt communist North Korea's nuclear weapons program -- which had been expected this month -- are likely to be put off until mid-January, South Korea's Yonhap news agency reported on Friday.

item.title: Pettitte Goes Home, Choosing Astros Over the Yankees (The New York Times)
item.description: The New York Times - Andy Pettitte leaves behind a nine-year legacy with the Yankees and leaves an enormous hole in the Yankee rotation.

item.title: Bush Defends Policy on Awarding Contracts to Rebuild Iraq (The New York Times)
item.description: The New York Times - President Bush explained his Iraq contract policy today by saying that "the expenditure of U.S. dollars will reflect the fact that U.S. troops and others risk their life."

item.title: German Judge Frees 9/11 Suspect, Citing New Evidence (The New York Times)
item.description: The New York Times - The judge's decision also raised questions about the conviction of another man in the case who was convicted on similar charges and sentenced to 15 years in prison.

item.title: Bush's Advisers Focus on Dean as Likely Opponent Next Year (The New York Times)
item.description: The New York Times - The advisers are planning a campaign that takes account of what they see as Howard Dean's strengths and weaknesses.

item.title: Court Ruling Affirms New Landscape of Campaign Finance (The New York Times)
item.description: The New York Times - Both parties will now have to operate on hard money donations, which Republicans have been more adept at soliciting.

item.title: Cluster bombs kill in Iraq, even after shooting ends (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - The little canisters dropped onto the city, white ribbons trailing behind. They clattered into streets, landed in lemon trees, rattled around on roofs, settled onto lawns.

item.title: Justices uphold key portions of new campaign financing law (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - The Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld the key parts of the nation's new campaign-finance law, backing a ban on unlimited donations to political parties and limits on broadcast ads in the weeks before elections.

item.title: Terror suspect's attorney lands in the spotlight (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - In her nearly 20 years as a criminal defense attorney, representing everyone from drug defendants to alleged racketeers, reporters have come knocking from time to time. "But I generally don't believe it's in my client's best interest to talk to the press," says Newman, 56.

item.title: Man held, suspected of al-Qaeda, Moussaoui ties (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Federal authorities took an unidentified man into custody in Minnesota this week as a material witness in a terrorism-related investigation, law enforcement sources said Wednesday.

item.title: Many Dems question Dean's chances (USATODAY.com)
item.description: USATODAY.com - Al Gore's endorsement of Howard Dean on Tuesday ended any question about whether the former Vermont governor has become the contender most likely to win the Democratic presidential nomination.

item.title: Bush Defends Barring Foes Of War From Iraq Business (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - President Bush yesterday fiercely defended his decision to bar France, Germany, Russia and Canada from Iraq reconstruction contracts, defying a furious outcry from allies and even objections from GOP and conservative leaders.

item.title: Halliburton Subsidiary May Have Overbilled (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - Defense Department auditors have discovered that a Halliburton Inc. subsidiary may have overcharged the government $61 million on a contract to supply fuel for Iraq, a Pentagon official said at a hurriedly called news conference last night.

item.title: McCain-Feingold Ruling Angers Activists on Both Left and Right (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - It's not every day the National Rifle Association and the American Civil Liberties Union are outraged by the same Supreme Court decision.

item.title: Federal Warning On Tuna Planned (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - The federal government plans to warn pregnant women, nursing mothers and even those thinking of getting pregnant to limit their consumption of tuna as part of a broad advisory concerning the dangers of eating fish and shellfish with elevated levels of harmful mercury.

item.title: President Warns Taiwan On Independence Efforts (washingtonpost.com)
item.description: washingtonpost.com - President Bush, with Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao at his side in the Oval Office, delivered a firm warning yesterday to the Taiwanese government over its aspirations for independence, telling the island's leaders not to pursue a referendum that has angered mainland China.
